question: A city government claims that building a new light-rail system will significantly reduce traffic congestion. The proposal is based on surveys showing high public interest in using public transportation.

options.A: Residents also support adding new bus routes.
options.B: Cities with similar light-rail systems have seen substantial reductions in traffic congestion.
options.C: The proposed light-rail line will require several years of construction.
options.D: Many residents currently commute by car.
options.E: The light-rail system will connect residential and commercial districts.

solution: Evidence that similar systems reduced congestion strengthens the claim that the new system will reduce congestion.

question: Researchers hypothesize that a new sleep supplement increases deep sleep duration. Early tests show a correlation between supplement use and increased time spent in deep sleep.

options.A: Participants also exercised more during the study period.
options.B: Participants using the supplement showed greater deep sleep increases than those taking a placebo.
options.C: The supplement contains natural ingredients.
options.D: Participants reported feeling more refreshed.
options.E: Deep sleep is associated with cognitive benefits.

solution: A controlled comparison against placebo provides strong evidence that the supplement itself improves deep sleep.

question: A tech company claims its new cybersecurity software reduces the risk of data breaches. The claim is based on internal tests showing fewer simulated intrusions.

options.A: The software is compatible with multiple operating systems.
options.B: Independent security firms verified the reduction in successful intrusion attempts.
options.C: The company has a strong track record of producing reliable software.
options.D: Most breaches in the past year were caused by human error.
options.E: The software requires annual updates.

solution: Third-party verification provides unbiased support for the company’s claim.

question: A restaurant claims its new vegan menu increased revenue because sales rose 15% after the menu’s introduction.

options.A: Customer satisfaction surveys show positive feedback on the new menu.
options.B: Nearby construction diverted foot traffic toward the restaurant.
options.C: The vegan dishes use locally sourced ingredients.
options.D: The restaurant expanded its seating capacity.
options.E: The rise in sales primarily occurred on weekends.

solution: If construction redirected more customers to the restaurant, the revenue increase may not be due to the vegan menu.

question: A company claims its new training program improved employee productivity because employees completed tasks faster afterward.

options.A: Employees enjoy the new training approach.
options.B: A new workflow automation tool was introduced during the same period.
options.C: Some employees found the training difficult.
options.D: The training program lasted only one week.
options.E: Employee turnover decreased.

solution: Automation, not training, might explain the productivity increase.

question: A university claims that offering more online courses increased graduation rates. They point to higher graduation numbers since expanding online classes.

options.A: Students appreciate the flexibility of online courses.
options.B: The university simultaneously increased financial aid availability.
options.C: Online courses require fewer classroom resources.
options.D: Professors received training to teach online.
options.E: Other universities experienced similar trends.

solution: More financial aid could increase graduation rates independently of online course availability.

question: A company plans to switch to biodegradable packaging, expecting this change to increase customer loyalty.

options.A: Customers value environmental sustainability.
options.B: Biodegradable packaging costs more to produce.
options.C: The company will maintain current product quality.
options.D: Competitors already use biodegradable packaging.
options.E: Customers prefer recyclable materials to biodegradable ones.

solution: The plan relies on customers caring about sustainability; otherwise loyalty would not increase.

question: A nutritionist claims that eliminating sugary drinks from school cafeterias will reduce student obesity rates.

options.A: Students will not compensate by consuming sugary drinks elsewhere.
options.B: Obesity is influenced by many lifestyle factors.
options.C: Schools can enforce drink restrictions.
options.D: Sugary drink sales contribute to school revenue.
options.E: Students prefer water to soda.

solution: The intervention only reduces obesity if students don’t simply get sugary drinks from other sources.

question: A business consultant argues that implementing a four-day workweek will not harm productivity because employees will work more efficiently.

options.A: Employees will not become more stressed due to longer daily hours.
options.B: Efficiency gains will fully offset the reduction in weekly hours.
options.C: Most employees are satisfied with their jobs.
options.D: Fewer hours reduce burnout.
options.E: Remote work has similar productivity benefits.

solution: The claim requires that efficiency improvements compensate enough to maintain productivity.

question: A school district expects that adding coding classes will improve overall student problem-solving skills.

options.A: How many teachers are qualified to teach coding?
options.B: Do students who take coding classes perform better on problem-solving assessments?
options.C: Is coding becoming more common in other school districts?
options.D: Will the new classes require new computers?
options.E: Do students enjoy learning coding?

solution: This directly tests whether coding improves problem-solving, which is the claim at issue.

question: A fitness company claims its new wearable device motivates users to exercise more.

options.A: Does increased device usage correlate with increased physical activity?
options.B: Does the device come in multiple colors?
options.C: Are similar devices available from competitors?
options.D: How accurate are the device’s sensors?
options.E: Does the device require frequent charging?

solution: To evaluate the claim, it's crucial to determine if the device actually influences exercise behavior.

question: A startup expects its AI-powered tutoring software to improve student grades based on early beta-testing feedback.

options.A: Were beta testers representative of the broader student population?
options.B: Are similar AI products available?
options.C: How much will the software cost schools?
options.D: Did teachers receive training to use the software?
options.E: Does the software require cloud access?

solution: If the testers are not representative, the expected results may not generalize, making this the key question.

question: All employees in Department A attend weekly training. Some employees in Department B also attend the training. No interns attend the training.

options.A: Some employees do not attend training.
options.B: Some people who attend training are not from Department A.
options.C: Interns attend training in other departments.
options.D: Only Department A employees attend training.
options.E: All employees in Department B attend training.

solution: Since some Department B employees attend training, not all trainees are from Department A.

question: A library loan policy states: All rare books must remain in the library. Some historical documents may be checked out. No rare books are historical documents.

options.A: Some historical documents are rare books.
options.B: All historical documents must remain in the library.
options.C: Some historical documents may leave the library.
options.D: Rare books may be checked out.
options.E: No books may be checked out.

solution: Historical documents can be checked out, and none are rare books.

question: Every project manager must submit a monthly report. Some analysts also submit monthly reports. No interns submit monthly reports.

options.A: Some people who submit reports are analysts.
options.B: All analysts submit reports.
options.C: Interns submit reports to their supervisors.
options.D: Only project managers submit reports.
options.E: Analysts are project managers.

solution: Since some analysts do submit reports, this must be true.

question: Consumer advocates argue that the proposed data-sharing policy should be rejected because it jeopardizes user privacy. However, a company spokesperson responds that privacy protections are adequate and that the policy is essential for improving service quality.

options.A: The first boldface presents the main conclusion; the second acknowledges a competing claim.
options.B: The first boldface provides evidence against a policy; the second presents a counterclaim supporting it.
options.C: The first boldface states background information; the second offers additional support.
options.D: Both boldface portions offer evidence supporting the main conclusion.
options.E: Both boldface portions acknowledge objections.

solution: The first argues against the policy; the second offers a counterclaim supporting it.

question: Environmentalists warn that expanding offshore drilling threatens marine ecosystems. Nevertheless, economists argue that increased domestic energy production will stabilize fuel prices.

options.A: The first boldface acknowledges a concern; the second provides evidence for the conclusion.
options.B: The first boldface is a claim opposed by the argument; the second boldface states the argument’s main conclusion.
options.C: The first boldface presents a potential negative outcome; the second presents a competing economic consideration.
options.D: Both boldface statements support the same conclusion.
options.E: The second boldface weakens the argument of the first.

solution: Environmental harm vs. economic benefit—two competing considerations.

question: Some commentators argue that reducing taxes will stimulate economic growth. Critics respond, however, that growth depends more on investment in public infrastructure.

options.A: The first boldface is a hypothesis; the second challenges its validity.
options.B: The first boldface offers background; the second states the main conclusion.
options.C: Both boldface statements support the same policy action.
options.D: The second boldface provides evidence for the first.
options.E: Both boldface statements describe economic outcomes.

solution: The second boldface challenges the theory presented in the first.

question: A new gym saw membership increase by 30%, yet total monthly revenue decreased.

options.A: The gym reduced membership fees for new sign-ups.
options.B: Members use the gym mostly on weekends.
options.C: The gym expanded its class offerings.
options.D: The gym hired more instructors.
options.E: The gym installed new equipment.

solution: More members paying less money explains falling revenue despite membership growth.

question: A school’s music program became more popular, but instrument sales at the school store dropped this year.

options.A: Students increasingly borrow instruments from the school’s rental program.
options.B: Students want more advanced music classes.
options.C: The store reduced advertising.
options.D: The music program received new funding.
options.E: More teachers joined the program.

solution: If students borrow instead of buy, popularity can increase while sales fall.

question: A city installed additional public trash bins, yet reports of littering increased.

options.A: The bins were placed mostly in low-traffic areas.
options.B: The city also hosted several large outdoor events.
options.C: Recycling initiatives increased.
options.D: The city raised fines for littering.
options.E: Some neighborhoods requested more bins.

solution: Large events generate extra litter regardless of bin availability.

question: The company plans to eliminate single-use plastics. This initiative is likely to succeed because ______.

options.A: single-use plastic bans are becoming more common globally
options.B: customers increasingly demand environmentally friendly packaging
options.C: the company recently updated its logo
options.D: the company competes with major retailers
options.E: the company’s sales increased last year

solution: Customer demand links directly to the success of the initiative.

question: The local government expects the new bike-sharing program to reduce pollution because ______.

options.A: bike-sharing is popular in neighboring cities
options.B: fewer people will need to drive short distances
options.C: the program uses colorful bicycles
options.D: the program is funded through grants
options.E: the city added more bus routes

solution: This option connects the program to reduced driving, which reduces pollution.

question: The research institute predicts that the shift to remote work will increase innovation because ______.

options.A: remote workers enjoy greater schedule flexibility
options.B: remote teams communicate more frequently through digital platforms
options.C: talent can now be recruited globally rather than locally
options.D: many employees prefer working from home
options.E: companies can reduce office expenses

solution: Global talent access is logically tied to increased innovation.
